review_blob: A truly wonderful beer. Thanks to Ashley for sharing this with me. A hazy drab orange-golden hue with a soft white head. Nose of mildly musky sweet tart candies. As tart as can be without overdoing it. Citrus, orange rind, and tangy lemon. Finishes with a tart lingering prickliness that is very quenching and satisfying. Dangerously delicious.
Medium brown bodies with a moderate whitish head. Nutty, chewy malt profile. Mild, crisp, refreshing. Sessionable American brown ale. Crisp, concise, and delicious.

Grower pour thanks to DJ and Matt. Nearly opaque black-brown body with a lasting biege head. Rich, toasty, robust, roasty nose. Some lasting citrus, piny hops, More like a hopped up porter on the nose, but lingering hops bitterness on palate. Dry, astringent and drinkable. Refreshing, crisp, and very clean. Nice beer!

2010-11 bottle from Pyramid. Standard orangy amber-copper hued with a healthy whitish head. Nice lacing. Nice neutral yeast beneath a chewy malt spine and rich bitter thick hoppiness. Some tropical fruit notes. Balanced but  Hop aroma lacks as compared to previous draught tastings. Labels suck but I am not rating based on label.

Can shared thanks to my friend DJ who obtained it from a friend Moline, IL. Deep reddish-brown ale with a clinging off-white head. Nutty, biscuity, bready nose. With some sweetness but balanced between sweet and dry. Faint off-ness; mild tart vegetal plastic presence. Some burn English yeastiness. Finishes dry. Overall okay. Likely better fresh on tap at source.
beer_name: Great River Roller Dam Red Ale

review_blob: Shared by Sean of 2 Beer Guys from a can. Hops appeared to drop out a bit. Golden-amber bodied with a clinging medium white head. Bready malts and yeast pair for a chewy slightly nutty character. This rating could be affected by the age of the beer or the fact that it was trucked and canned from early summer 10 at Saranac. Fresh, it could be better. To be continued...

From Burts Better Beers in Hooksett, New Hampshire. Merlot batch 1. From a pricy 750 ml bottle, corked and caged, this particular brew poured a yellow pale hue with a bright vinous aroma yet with some cutting solvent nose and a flavor to match. Overtly forward booziness and ferocious phenolic kick. Personally, not a pleasurable beer. Drain pour. Looking for positive angle on this brew and respect inventiveness, but beer missed the mark gravely.

From a bottle shared by Sean of 2 Beer Guys. This orange-copper-amber hazy bodied ale possesses a frothy attached whitish head. The nose is a luring piny citrus Northwest hop variety with prevalent bready and biscuity undertones as well as noticeable nuttiness. Clean, balanced (for an IPA) with many favorable resinous hops complexities. This beer is an obvious winner.

Save for Astoria Brewings Bitter Bitch Triple IPA, Ninkasi Critical Hit, from what we gathered, was one of the hoppiest brews at the Lucky Lab Barleywine and Big Beer Fest, and likely the hoppiest barleywine. Lots of toffee and piny tropical fruit notes came from this deep tawny beer. This beer could have almost passed for an triple IPA, but there was some noticeable caramel maltiness present. Very bitter on the tongue, but overall, this is the kind of barleywine many Pacific Northwestern beer lovers like, and Ninkasi aint no dummy.

Yellow golden clear filtered body with neat whitish head. Piquant pissy hippy node with lager yeast presence. Crisp, refreshingly, no diacytel. A bit more aggressive than traditional German Pilsners but well made and uber clean.

Light tawny bodied Opaque with amber and copper tints. Semi-floral nose with detection of citrus PNW hops. Low pininess, thin bo dy with relatibely watery mouthfeel. Lots of Columbus hops. Unmoving but well built.

Deep bronze-brown hue with lasting off-white capping. See through, clear filtered. Nose of sweet crisp malts and faint nutty chocolatiness. Clean, no diacytel. Mild roasted husk bitterness/acidity. Excellent representation of style, especially for Ne brewery.
Dark ruddy gritty drab orange hue. Soft white head. Served w lemon. Astringient, cloying and unbalanced. Poor example of style.

Thanks to Theo for sharing a few years of this at Baileys BA/RB gathering. Rich as would be expected of a barleywine. Caramel cloying, molasses, dark fruit, spices, chewy, some dead hops in there. Not bad, not great.

Theres been a lot of buzz about Dark Horse in recent months. Maybe longer, but I have just caught wind. The Crooked Tree was the hoppy beer of the lot and the one we finished our tasting with, as it is an Imperial India Pale Ale. From Marshall Michigan, this is a true double. According the the label on the bottle, all of the ingredients of Dark Horses standard IPA were doubled, save for water. It isnt a groundbreaking brew by any means, but crafted perfectly for hop heads who want an imperial with a nice ratio of bitterness to aroma. Dark amber bodied with a frothy cream-colored head. I havent been drinking a lot of DIPAs lately, but this is one I am glad I tried. End of palate. Good night.
beer_name: Dark Horse Double Crooked Tree IPA

review_blob: Deep tawny-golden color with a frothy off-white head. Lots of legs clinging to side of snifter as I stirred it. Molasses, oak, rich malt, and a hint of vanilla bean in the nose. Very complex and new flavors presented themselves as it warmed. Thanks to Carl for sharing. Very nice!
beer_name: Odell Woodcut No. 02 Oak Aged Golden Ale

review_blob: Poured a hazy orange-yellow body with thick off-white head. Lots of yeasty esters and nice NW floral hops. Fruity, piny, mild on the tongue and very sessionable. Not overly complex, but quite interesting hybridization of styles

Amber copper bodied NW IPA with moderate white lasting head. Spicy hops and mildly smoky yerba aroma. Acidic and bitter, moderately slick on tongue. A substantial malt backbone, but mostly driven by the herbal character of both the hops and the yerba mate. Good level of CO2, clean and overall refreshing. I love yerba mate, so I may be rather partial to this one.

Head spinningly sour. This murky orange-golden beer with a tint of ruby is opaque and without a head. Very tart and shocking on the tongue but somewhat balanced by oak tannins and Ceylon cinnamon. Almost like lemon-grapefruit juice in appearance and flavor, but more tart. Another great depiction of what New Belgium is doing with their line-up of sours.
beer_name: New Belgium Lips of Faith - Tart Lychee

review_blob: On tap at Green Dragon in Portland, OR. Poured a deep brown with a big whitish head. Nutty, metallic body. Kind of throw-up-like. I suppose I could drink a lot of this, but I wouldnt really want to. Rather boring porter, not very hopped, more like an English mild ale.

Bottle enjoyed at Beer Mongers in Portland, Oregon. Tart, sharp and all the sourness wed hoped for. Dry, puckering flavors emerged from this golden-copper bodied hazy beer. Very nice fruity complexities with some tingly snap. Boo yah!

Picked up this can at New Seasons market in SE Portland. Poured a deep, dark black body with tints of amber. Frothy, well lasting gray-brown head. Chocolaty, malten nose. Metallic presence on the tongue. As more sips were experiences, this beer became more pleasurable. True to style for a schwartzbier. Crisp, session worthy, and mildly nutty. Not bad.

Heres a beer from one of Canadas most obscure breweries. Brewed on the small island off Quebecs eastern coast, this brewery uses all organic and sustainable practices to produce a line-up of phenomenal malt-driven brews. Terre Ferme adds exceptional (for the region) bitterness as well as vegetal notes that come across like a mild ginger. If you ever have the chance to try one of lAbri de la Temptes excellent beers, get on it.
beer_name: lAbri de la Tempte Terre Ferme

review_blob: Heres a beer that further exhibits using low hops to the best of ones ability. A wonderful session-worthy brown ale with a world of nuttiness. Its the kind of dry, cake-like, softly fruity brew that you wish you could go back for again and again. The fact that it comes in 16 ounce, er.. 473 ml cans makes it pleasing for those of us who appreciate a craft brew in a can. At just 4.8% ABV, it wont ruin you. Excellente!

Smoke owns the character of this deep, chewy nectar. Lots of molasses, coffee, toffee, and chocolate notes linger underneath the smoldering  malt mayhem. Some say this one is the Lagavulin of beer and as it warms, more in your face flavor reveals itself. Not much to look at, this beer has little head to it, but the dull dark brown ureminds me of a weeklong camping trip with a lot of time by the old fire. Some mild lactic hints far off in the distance that gives it some semblance of balance,  if not cheesiness. This beer was built to pair with sharp cheddar and salty crackers.  All features of this beer bows down to the smoke. What a brew! Tres bien!

This spectacular brewery from Shawinigan, Quebec produces some of Canadas finest ales. The Buteuse is the abbey trippel. At 10% ABV, the alcohol is well masked with lots of fruity notes akin to pineapple and pear. Bubbly, amber bodied, and dry, this delicious beer is one of the best gifts our Canadian compatriot has ever given us. Thank you, Marc!
beer_name: Le Trou du Diable Buteuse Brassin Spcial (Brandy Oak)

review_blob: ESBs may not be in vogue these days, but a well built bitter is unlike anything else. A nice nutty brownish amber pour with thick off-white, lasting head caps a wold of bitter sweet aromas a touch of herbal hops and caramelly sweetness. La Folle ESB is both creamy and resinous; everything fans of the style could hope for. In a land where hops dont abound as they do here, the creative brewers at Charlevoix. Artist Denis Reid is the man behind this brewerys spectacular labels.

This beer is not trying to over impress but it is well built and spectacularly balanced.With a big white head and a light golden bodied spicy blonde ale, this beer offers flares of  both woodiness and  hoppiness. A snap of cereal grains and a pleasant grassy hop finish. Fresh fruitiness with a world of soft complexity. I would really love to see a beer like this pouring regularly around town.

This imperial India Pale Ale from Microbrasserie dOrlans/Pub Le Mitan is a bold autumn seasonal with a light citrus presense and some key floral notes to support a boisterously maltilicious underpinning. A warm upfront alcohol presence is likely designed to cut through the Northeasts chillier months. An amalgumation of English and Northwest IPA styles, and not the best DIPA ever, but quite good, and the handsome artwork is rather luring.

Thanks to our friend Marc for this unique take on a pumpkin brew. subtle spiciness with a great presence of effervescent Belgian yeast. Crisp and refreshing with a nice bready finish. Golden-amber bodied with a soft white head. Well paired with sweet, rich foods or as served by itself.

Small white head with a faint crisp, grainy nose to match a similar rather sweet palate. Not true to style for a pilsner. Some stickiness with a flowery hops character. Nothing much to write home about.

Poured from a 330 ml bottle a dark aubergine/chestnut hue with no head and a fragile wispy, soapy top. Malt driven nose with some dark fruity character. Chewy yet relatively mild and wort-y. Mild woody character relaxes a subtle delicate thin finish with a few residual boozy bursts.

From Belmont Station in Portland, OR...Poured a light mustard orange murky hue with a soft whitish bubbly thin head.  Nose of mildly dull citrus notes and a watery fruits.  Low carbonation levels no pop when uncapping and thin on the tongue.  Finished a little disappointingly drab.  Somehow it remained on the back of the tongue a quasi cloying manner.  Eh.

On tap at Green Dragon on Halloween 2008--Soapy yellow-orange hazed body and a medium white head. Grainy, yeasty, nutty nose with a wonderful mouthfeel.  Mildly bitter and thoroughly enjoyable.  I totally dug it.
Thanks to Ezra for sharing this bottle at his Scotch tasting.  Poured a deep brown mildly chestnut hue with a thin taupe head. Satisfyingly smoky and rich.  Malt driven and wonderfully flavorsome.

On tap at Green Dragon, this wonderfully rich and dry medium bodied brew poured a hardy brown-black body with a thick beige-tan head.  On nitro, it is fluffy, with hints of biscuit and chewy grains.  A wonderful NW interpretation of a classic style.  Yum!

From a 500 ML bottle from By the Bottle in Vancouver, WA--RIch, dark hue.  Brown-black with a round, fluffy tan head.  Nutty, creamy, chocolate nose.  Easy drinking, not thick on the tongue, but rich in complexities.  Great beer from a great brewery.

Bottle from Belmont Station in Portland, OR--Poured a rich dark mostly black, slightly brown thick rich body with a creamy off-white head.  Nose of rich thick malt, chocolate, toffee, and dark fruity yeastiness.  Great roasted character.  Hints of vanilla, liquorish, rasins, and the sweetness of a Baltic Porter balanced by chalky deep cacao.  Excellent beer!

22 bucks for an 11oz. bottle.  Thats $2 an ounce.  Jeepers!  Poured a murky flat brown-chestnut body.  Ruddy like syrupy salad dressing.  Vinegar, sour nose.  with an oaken touch.  Mild, soft finish.  Hint of berries and barnyard yeastiness.  I would definitely never pay for this beer.  While interesting and somewhat akin to Rodenbach Grand Cru, I would rather drink something else, especially considering the price tag.  Over-rated.

I have never nor would I ever put this swill to my lips.  I smelled it and that is enough to over rate it 0.5 here.  I mean, I have smelled a steaming pile of dog doo (not up close or on purpose) and know the same is true:  do not ingest!

Pours a deep black, brown body with a thin whitish head.  Spicy, carbonic nutty and hoppy nose. Tingles the nostrils. Mildly metallic and malty with a big hop spiciness. Very nice NW Porter style.  Crisp, clean, and refreshing.

Thanks to Ron Gansberg for all of his generosity!  Rich amber-bronze hue with a minuscule head.  vinous, sour, Rodenbach-esque.  Tangy, vegetal and fruity.  Quite distinct and textured.  The alcohol is well masked though it becomes more evident as the beer warms. Great beer!

Thanks to the kind folks at BridgePort for this wonderful brew--Poured a deep dark abysmal black body with a minimal wispy whitish head.  Spicy roasted nose.  Rich, chalky and carbonic.  Hints of chocolate and spicy hops.  Prickly mouthfeel jumping with NW hops.  RObust malt character carried this beer.  The oak was more less than subtle.  Very mild barrel flavor.   Perhaps a little vinous grip from the Pinot Noir.  Overall, a wonderfully rich and complex porter.

Oktoberfest brew on tap at Laurelwood brewpub on 51st and NE Sandy Blvd in Portland, OR--Poured a light color for a marzen.  More maibock-like.  Small wispy, wimpy white head.  Nutty, sweet, caramel nose.  Lots of bold malts.  A bit cloying, but overall pretty nice.

2008 Fresh Hop Pale on tap at Laurelwood brewpub on 51st and NE Sandy Blvd in Portland, OR--Mild orange-amber body with a swirly white head.  Grass, earthy and English yeastiness.  Lots of green Liberty hops own this beer.  I was at Annen Bros farm the day they harvests these hops.  Sweet!

Bottle from By the Bottle in Vancouver, WA--Poured a deep dark brown-black opaque body with an attractive off-white thick head.  Roasted chocolate and caramel malty nose.  Thick like a stout.  Mildly metallic and bitter.  Very hoppy.  Nive NW Porter!

11.2 ounce bottle from Bottleworks in Seattle, WA--Exploding, cascading, Vesuvius, super carbonated head.  1/3 of it ended on the counter top.  Hazy, orange-amber body with a thick three-finger meringue head.  Sweet, fruity bubblegum nose with spicy clove and coriander notes.  Yeasty esters.  Sharp effervescent mouthfeel.  Musky flavor that lingers astringent and attenuated.  Sweet and musty finish.  Lost of oniony and gritty hops linger on back of tongue.

11.2 ounce bottle from Bottleworks in Seattle, WA--Bubbly copper-body with a thick dirty white head. Creamy saccharine nose.  Nutty, mildly floral.  Creamy all the way through.  Not a lot of bite in the finish but extremely drinkable and flavorful.

22 ounce bottle from By the Bottle in Vancouver, WA--Another worthy offering from Southern Tier.  Pours an almost headless opaque black body with tinges of burgundy around the edges.  Chocolate, nutty, boozy nose.  Oats shine through and help balance super bold malts.  Hops also contribute to spicing and leveling the weight of this beast.  Very nice complexity to this beer.  Subtle dark fruit flavors backdrop a thick chocolate spine with a clean soft finish.

500ml bottle obtained from Belmont Station in Portland, OR--Exploded with carbonation upon opening.  Dark brown-chestnut body with a floating thin tan head.  Musty, sour, solvent tannin nose.  Assertive and tart off the bat, but mellows on the back of the tongue.  Less forceful than many sours.  Well-built and nice with sharp cheese.  Fruity, clean cherry presence that gently lingers.
